results.name: Table T(n,k) giving number of ways of obtaining exactly one correct answer on an (n,k)-matching problem (1 <= k <= n).
comment: Hanson et al. define the (n,k)-matching problem in the following realistic way. A matching question on an exam has k questions with n possible answers to choose from, each question having a unique answer. If a student guesses the answers at random, using each answer at most once, what is the probability of obtaining r of the k correct answers?
The T(n,k) represent the number of ways of obtaining exactly one correct answer, i.e., r=1, given k questions and n possible answers, 1 <= k <= n.
link: D. Hanson, K. Seyffarth and J. H. Weston, Matchings, Derangements, Rencontres, Mathematics Magazine, Vol. 56, No. 4, September 1983.
formula: T(n,k) = k*T(n-1,k-1) + T(n-1,k) with T(n,1) = 1 and T(n,n) = A000240(n). [Hanson et al.]
maple: A076732:=proc(n,k): (k/(n-k)!)*A047920(n,k) end: A047920:=proc(n,k): add(((-1)^j)*binomial(k-1,j)*(n-1-j)!, j=0..k-1) end: seq(seq(A076732(n,k), k=1..n), n=1..10); # _Johannes W. Meijer_, Jul 27 2011
